Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2010 12:50PM gutsy wrote: Mammo results when worrisome can be quick. I can only speak for myself, but when when there were no concerns with mammogram no discussion or anything happened during the mammogram. For my last mammogram when things did not appear so well, I had an ultrasound right after. Radiologist came in, etc. I knew before I left there that there were issues. However, eventhough the results were in the next day (I found that out later) physician's office did not call untill a week later. I was scared to call, thinking no news is good news. I am glad I did call and got the ball rolling.
Posts.Title: How long for mammo Results dillars dillars

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2010 04:31PM gutsy wrote: I had a diagnostic mammogram done after finding a lump, and yes the ultrasound right after eventhough it was scheduled for the next week. I have learned in a very short period of time to be pro-active about my own healthcare.
Posts.Title: How long for mammo Results dillars dillars

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2010 12:27PM gutsy wrote: Basia, know there is lots of support here every step of the way. I have 3 children and the last year I have been on autopilot taking care of everyone elses needs. I could not even make time to get my hair cut, let alone go for a mammogram with a 2 year old. We are going to move forward, and take care of ourselves and have others help in our care. Don't try to diagnose yourself, it will make you scared and overwhelmed. Take one day at a time, I am trying hard myself to do that, and know that there are many women here who will support you. I am amazed each time when I am feeling so overwhelmed that there are women here who will comfort me with their words in a very short period of time. They don't judge, they understand and they reach out. You are going to make it through, one step at a time. It sounds like you have lovely daughters and a supportive husband. Hugs for you

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2010 01:54PM gutsy wrote: Good for you Molly to seek out some help. It sounds like you did not have a lot of support while you were going through all your treatment. you may feel hurt at that. You also deserved to be treated with care, support and respect and lots of love. You handled it all as a true warrior woman, but at a high cost to yourself. The sad reality is that there are no rewards or badges of honour for those of us who still try to do everything ourselves despite our difficult cancer journey. People may actually feel relieved when they see people like you handling it all, and think it can't be so bad. I can understand some of your frustration, but it hurts you. Yep, how the media views it can often be misleading. It is better to turn the page than read stuff like that. It would piss me off too.

Posts.Content: gutsy wrote: I know that I have a IDC lump under 1 cm (hope that is correct), I was also told by my surgeon that there are some calcifications in the same breast. She wants to know what they are prior to lumpectomy and scheduled an MRI. I am in Canada, and getting an MRI is really difficult. I had the MRI on Friday. Howver, I have been scheduled for surgery next Friday. Will they be able to tell if they are pre-cancerous or cancer by the MRI? Would they need to do a biopsy before Friday. Is there such a thing as having a lumpectomy at the same time in two places, one for the lump and one to remove the calcifications. I am looking at at MRI images of breast calcifications on the internet and trying to diagnose myself and figure out if I will have a lumpectomy or mastectomy. After I completed the MRI I saw one picture which showed the lump and calcifications in my left breast. So I am kind of going crazy right now. Oh, I am sorry that I am so all over the place. I saw the surgeon 3 weeks ago, and as far as I know will not see her untill surgery day. I am kind of in a vacuum. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2010 07:40AM gutsy wrote: I think that the MRI will give your surgeon and you more clarity about the amount of DCIS and were it is located. If it is multi-focal (in many different areas) is very difficult to do a lumpectomy with good cosmetic results. Not having the time or patience to go through extended radiation may be a valid reason for you to chose a mastectomy. Than ofcourse there is the whole question of reconstruction or not which are also major issues. Unfortunately, no matte what route you chose it is going to be challenging and will interfere with life.
Posts.Title: Mastectomy versus Lumpectomy and Radiation Ruthlo JanetinVirginia

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2012 08:46PM gutsy wrote: Barb, I would find it helpful if people spoke from their own experiences and would be upfront about their own diagnosis. I see you respond to many threats, and I wonder where you are coming from. Is it your own lived experiences. I think it is human nature to be somewhat ticked off when people at a much lower stage pipe in on the experiences of those at a higher stage. I find it really hard when stage 0 dcis people feel that their experience is similar to those of us with higher grade IDC. I still remember the physician saying to me, "you don't have the good kind"  So, I want to be respectfull of those with a more advanced stage than mine.
Posts.Title: Why am I only ok talking to stage III ladies?feeling like a jerk Josiekat lkc

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2010 11:43PM gutsy wrote: I had a diagnostic mammogram and the radiologist did not come into the room. However, the tech person checked with the radiologist before I was allowed to get dressed again. I had an ultrasound the same day, and the radiologist did come in and guided the technician for a little while, telling her were to put the wand. Than he left. If there possible areas of concern, I believe the radiologist comes in to check etc. Does not mean that something is abnormal. They want to check more closely.
Posts.Title: Radiologist ???? OkieDoe gutsy

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2011 01:03PM gutsy wrote: Every 5 yrs seems absolutely ridiculous. It certainly does not seem best practice for women who have a history of breast cancer.  I do think that the amount of scanning that goes on is also very dependent on the country's health system. I have noticed on the boards that US resident with insurance get a heck of a lot more scans than those of us in Canada. My oncologist will only do scans if there are symptoms that warrant it. I also understand that CT scans, Bone Scans etc give out a ton of radiation, so it is also about weighing the risks and the benefits.

I feel like you took it up a notch with me. Now, I know where you are coming from. It is not that I need to know every little detail, but it certainly helps me put things into perspective. Posts.Title: hello babysister66 babysister66

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2011 11:33PM gutsy wrote: I am so sorry to hear you have been recently diagnosed. I am going to say being diagnosed with breast cancer is a journey with unpredictable roads. My advice would be to take it one step at a time and listen to your body. I can totally understand you wanting to get this show on the road and be back to normal as soon as possible. There is going to be a new normal, and there is grieving involved. Some people do really well after the surgery and are up and doing things after a week, others take longer. Two weeks, four weeks, six weeks off work it does not really make a difference in the big picture. For many of us, surgery is the first step, and based on the pathology report other treatments may come into play. I had a unilateral with immediate reconstruction about a week ago. I am amazed at how much I can do again, the energy I have, etc. A lot easier than I thought. Plastic surgeon is addement that I take at least 4 weeks off. It is ofcourse for my physical healing, but don't forget your emotional healing. Don't rush back to work. It is better to be good and ready than to go back too soon.
Posts.Title: Questions about Mastectomy irish22 LG300

Posts.Content: May 28, 2011 04:55AM gutsy wrote: I totally understand. I have also been having these pains in my lower back and in my lower right abdomen. I had pain last year in my abdomen and it went away. It feels like it is back. I feel worried again and my mind is going where I get so scared. I am also on Tamoxifen and have started the stairmaster in the gym. I never seem to have a time of calm, something will feel weird and I feel panicky. I was supposed to go away with two of my kids for the long weekend, but I got too panicky before leaving. The thought of being out in the woods with nothing much to do besides relaxing scared me. At least at home, I can put my mind on the many loads of laundry and everything else that needs to be done. I do feel sometimes like sitting in the middle of the floor and just crying because I am often so afraid. I have to go for an ultrasound next week because of this bumpy area besides my alloderm implant.
Posts.Title: Back Pain/Worry Again pupfoster1 AnacortesGirl

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2012 04:50PM - edited Jan 1, 2012 04:52PM by gutsy I supposedly started out with a 8mm tumour, little bump on the road I was told, lumpectomy and radiation. The pathology report after lumpectomy, showed a much larger tumour and a few of them. The surgeon read out the whole report to me, page after page. I think I shut down after page 2. All I remembered was that I needed a mastectomy and chemo. I did the chemo before the mastectomy. There was no evidence of invasive cancer after the chemo.  I still can't read the report.
Posts.Title: Calling All with Tumors 6 cm + J-Bug CaliKelly

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2010 09:59PM gutsy wrote: Good for you to get a second opinion to put your mind at ease. I do believe that radiologist can not say with certainty what something is. They can rate it interms of how suspicious it is. A biopsy is the only way to tell for sure if something is benign or malignant. My experience with a diagnostic clinic was also a back and forward discussion between ultrasound technician and radiologist of what they could see or could not see. I can tell you that they totally forgot that I was there, me the patient. I would rather have them err on the side of caution than to take things to litely and say come back in 6 months. Wishing you b9 results. You need to be your own best advocate, so it is good that you will be seeing a breast surgeon/specialist

The bedside manners I have encountered so far have been almost like a comedy of errors. Physician (at clinic, I had never met before) rolled over his chair and said not good news, and shuffed a piece of paper under me. I had all my questions, but he said you are steps ahead of yourself. It can only go up from here, The surgeon I am meeting with has a very good reputation and has written a book "The intelligent Patient Guide to Breast Cancer".  I guess they don't have a breast cancer book for dummies. I promise one day soon I will return the support and care I feel here, right now I am not able to do much more than eat broccoli and carrots.

Posts.Title: Help suspcious mammogram and ultrasound for cancer gutsy flopsy

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2010 10:43PM gutsy wrote: I am wondering if you also had an ultrasound, the mammogram and ultrasound together give a clearer picture. Yes, it is the biopsy that determines whether or not it is malignant. In my view, if it looks suspicious it should be checked out further. Given your strong family history I think you would want to have it checked out. In my personal opinion, the statements "you are too young for BC and/or 80% are benign give women a false sense of security.  Likely it is benign, but you want to be sure of it so that you can have peace of mind.
Posts.Title: I know the stats but still worried..... rn4babies rn4babies

Posts.Content: gutsy wrote: I spoke to my oncologist about having MRIs in the future for screening of my other breast which is currently cancer free (hopefully will stay that way). I did have a MRI after being diagnosed with breast CA, which actually showed more ca than initially thought. He stated that the jury is still out whether or not this would be more beneficial than a diagnostic mammogram for detecting cancer.  Furthermore, he stated it is not funded. You can do it if you want, but I would not necesarily recommend it. Not the answer I wanted to hear. I would love to hear your opinions and experiences. I live in Canada and it would probably cost me $2000 to have it done each year. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: MRI for follow-up in the future gutsy vinicaka

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2010 04:05PM gutsy wrote: I would think there are student counselling services at the college you are going? Did you tap into that? They may be able to help you access different services, medical, psychological and some financial. It seems reasonable to take a semester out of school while you are dealing with all of this. I don't think they would kick you out, they may defer you once you give them a letter from your physician. If you have pneumonia it makes sense that they don't want you around patients. You need to take care of yourself right now. Hope that the results will provide you with some calmness in the storm you are going through.

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2011 12:59AM gutsy wrote: I had 4 rounds of chemo and than a unilateral mastectomy, reduction on the other side and reconstruction. I thought the surgery was much easier on me. The chemo affected me physically and emotionally. I felt so, so sick for 5 days after the infusion. I also felt so down. I could cry about nothing. Well, I had lots of things to cry about.  The surgery was fine. Initially a lot of pain, but on day two I was feeling pretty ok. Yes, the drains were a nusuance etc, I remember being so scared of the surgery, but it was so much easier on me than I had expected.  Congratulations on finishing your chemo. Yes, take it one step at a time. Next is surgery focus on that, and after that you can think about the radiation.

Posts.Title: surgery tomorrow, please hold me in your thoughts and prayers gutsy Gabrielledr

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2010 12:27AM gutsy wrote: JuliaBelle I was scheduled for a mammogram, and 1 week later for the ultrasound. I went for the mammogram and ended up having the ultrasound right away. I have BC. Actually the Ultrasound Technician informed me that she had another person in another room. They squeezed me in because they found something. It is good to have the ultrasound, because ultrasounds sheds more light on what the mass could be and depending on that they may or may not schedule a biopsy. Remember 80 % of biopsies are benign. Good that you have a mammogram every year, you are doing all the right things. Take a deep breath, and another one and take care of yourself.
Posts.Title: How long did you wait for an ultrasound? JuliaBelle JuliaBelle

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2010 11:14PM gutsy wrote: Juliabelle, the ultrasound will give a good indication whether the lump is filled with fluid or whether it is more solid. Based on the ultrasound and mammogram results they would give the lump a birad score. If they feel a biopsy is needed an appointment would be set. Could be set in the next couple of days. The biopsy would be done by radiologist or surgeon depending on the kind of biopsy it is and the availability of appointments. Core needle biopsy is a very simple technique which is really quite quick and from my experience not painful or scary. Receiving the results can vary from a couple of days to a week. Again it really depends on the clinic and how they operate. Wishing you B9 results and a sense of calmness during the next couple of days. The anxiety is crazy making. I am having an MRI done on Thursday and I am starting to get tunnel vision and stomach problems. Hugs Gutsy
Posts.Title: How long did you wait for an ultrasound? JuliaBelle JuliaBelle

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2010 12:21PM gutsy wrote: I am so sorry you are going through all this at such a young age. As if it is not hard enough to move across the ocean and start a new life. I can't help you with your first question, I am not from the area. Interms of work, I would not say too much yet. You don't know what your diagnosis is and the treatment path. We all hope it is a crazy mastisis or some cyst. I can tell you from my experience that treatment did not start the next day. I have worked in between treatments and kept things running at work as much as I could. Employers don't want a lot of hassle, so I would not give them anything that could make them turn around and let you go. You sound like a caring person, wanting to be fair etc, but the important thing is to look after yourself and do what is good for you. First you need to know what your diagnosis is and possible treatment plan, than you can give further information to your employer. I am trying to schedule my second surgery around the only person,who has done my job before, holidays. So there will be the least interruption to the program and the team. I think the surgeon's office thinks I am nuts and I should focus on my care. So, I am not one to speak.

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2011 07:05PM - edited Jun 21, 2011 07:06PM by gutsy Vivie I am sorry to hear that there is so much confusion you are experiencing. Don't get ahead of yourself. My recommendation is to write down all the questions you have and pose them to your medical team members. They are the experts and should be able to guide you. You need to know from them exactly what type of breast cancer you have and what are the options for treatment. Your surgeon and/or oncologist should go over the pathology report with you and explain what the terms mean. I am assuming you are referring to the biopsy pathology report. After surgery you get another pathology report that will really direct your treatment. Ofcourse they need to take your implant into consideration as much as possible.  I started out with a lumpectomy, but it was discovered that the calcifications that were picked up by the mammogram were dcis, and I ended up with a mastectomy. I am glad I did have the mastectomy. I did not need radiation.

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2010 01:02PM gutsy wrote: Thank you all for your support and comfort, I certainly felt your presence. It was a long day. Had the radio-active dye put in at one hospital, off to the other hospital for putting in the fine wires. Short talk with the surgeon who stated that the additional calcifications were still a mystery, but would be removed. I had asked for conscious sedation, but she stated that to avoid complications given the length of the surgery it was not advised. Ok, it was general anestetic. Prior to the surgery I got all these coughing fits, so I was given ventalin. I felt like a real patient yesterday. I actually worked at that hospital in the past for 5 yrs, so saying hi to past-coworkers in a surgical gown was not what I had planned on. I was one of 5 ladies being operated on for breast ca by my surgeon that morning. I am in some pain, but nothing a bit of tylenol can't cope with. I am still planning to take a few days of work. This was one step in the journey and many more to come. It was not pleasant, but very doable. I had this lovely technician who assisted the radiologist with the wire. She really was like an angel in disguise. It really helps to have caring, compassionate caregivers along this path. And caring ladies like yourself who understand, are real and available at the click of the keyboard.

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2010 12:32PM gutsy wrote: Have an ultrasound done on your breast, see a breast specialist, or a dermatologist at the very least NOW. Don't wait untill after your child is born. Very likely not anything serious, however, if it is something serious such as cancer, waiting for such a long time could be life threatening. Young women do get cancer, often they get misdiagnosed by their gp's, by the time someone takes them serious, it is not a pretty picture.

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2010 04:27PM gutsy wrote: Oh, I am with you. I feel every twitch in my body. When I first found the lump, I was touching it all the time and self-diagnosing. Yes, it is round, maybe oval. Feeling under my armpit, wanting to feel under other people's armpits (lol) to see what was normal. I don't touch anything anymore because it gets me completely spun out. I have backpain from a previous car accident, now I am scared it is not from the accident. First time in my life I have high blood pressure, I have always had low. So, yes stress is doing a number on me. At the same time, when I am not stressed, I think I am in denial and that is even more dangerous. What a rollercoaster ride, will I ever feel somewhat normal again. Or is it fear from now on.

Posts.Title: It's finally here - my 5 yr Cancerversary dreamwriter twoshoes

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2010 10:14PM gutsy wrote: I am so sorry to hear what is going on for you. It is not uncommon to have a clear mammogram and than a few months later find a lump. Frightening for sure. When speaking to my integrative health doc who is a MD, he informed me that it is not uncommon for hormonal cancers to pop up quickly. It does not mean that they are Her2+. In his experience, he has seen a lot of women who were diagnosed with breast cancer after having a number of significant stressors in their live, big live events. Increase of inflamation in the body, immune system down etc. That is one very symplistic view. I totally understand how it is easy to get ahead of yourself and start diagnosing yourself. If you can try to just take one day at a time and don't get ahead of yourself. I was feeling my lump all the time, and underneath my armpits. I was certain that my nodes were significantly swollen. When the breast surgeon checked them out, she stated that they felt normal.  Is your gp referring you to a breast surgeon? In my view it should be quite soon, it does not mean you have surgery right away, but at least the ball starts rolling.

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2011 07:08PM - edited Jan 12, 2011 07:18PM by gutsy I had surgery on the 6th and got my drain out on the 11. All the bandages came off except for the terra strips. I have to wear a sports bra now 24 hours a day. My real breast is bigger than the new one, the surgeon told me that it will go down in size on its own in the next couple of weeks. I hope so.  I should explain that I had a reduction and lift on that side. I hate to be the lob-sided woman after all this.  I am doing good overall, I have gone for 45 minute walks, do some laundry, dishes, etc. No heavy lifting. Friends and family are surprised to see me up and about.  My mother-in-law is coming tomorrow from Toronto to help. I think I have to be like the wolf from red riding hood. Before she comes, Put on some flannel pajamas, a little hat and pull the covers high up. I can't be out there going to a restaurant for lunch and checking out the January sales, that is what I did today

Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2011 02:51PM - edited Jan 7, 2011 02:53PM by gutsy Hello All, Update I am home  I had my unilateral mastectomy and alloderm reconstruction yesterday morning at 7:30 am. Lift on the other side to be exact. It went fairly smooth. It took about 2.5 hours. I apparently woke up ready to jump of the bed, but otherwise felt fine after the anestetic. No nausea, just slightly drowsy. Still wearing my own underwear (had forgotten to take it off before going into the OR) Received some fentanol for pain and from there on Tylenol 3. The area feels tight, but not too sore. It is important to stay on top of the pain, what I learned is that when you have a lot of pain your body can't heal and your muscles cramp up. I have one drain that looks like a plastic pancake which is clipped to my shirt. I have to drain it every 12 hours. Apparently my surgeon will take it out upcoming Tuesday. What really helped me stay focussed and calm was the kind nurses I came across. I had been worried about being under for that lenghth of time, but took 4 deep breaths from the oxygen and next thing I knew was that I was awakened from a slumbering very short dream. Never got to wear my sun slippers, the hospital supplied me with some anti-slip socks.  One of the things worth mentioning is that if you are taking a lot of vitamins and supplements, it is important to stop some of these about 7 days before surgery. For example, I had to stop  - Garlic pills - Tumeric pills - Omega 3 fish oil pills - Green tea extract pills - offcourse aspirin. all of these apparently could cause bleeding  I am feeling ok, thinking of going for a walk, but at the same know that I have to take it easy.
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2011 01:47PM gutsy wrote: Good to hear everyone who had surgery is doing ok. Ok is good under our circumstances. Is anyone else experiencing severe itching? I am told to wear a sports bra day and night, I am not sure if that is causing it? I am also taped up. My surgeon does not want patients to use cream, potions or lotions on their breast to prevent scarring and uses paper tape instead. The itching gets worse as the day progresses. In the scheme of things not the biggest deal in the world, but just wondering if it is just me?
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2011 08:14PM - edited Jan 23, 2011 08:14PM by gutsy Good luck to all of you who have surgery this week. I can say with certainty that it was less scary and easier than I thought. Take it easy afterwards and let others spoil you. Be a woman of leisure for at least the first two weeks after.  I did not make a special list of things to bring to the hospital. I did not bring much of anything and did not really have to. I put a housecoat, a book and some slippers in a bag which my husband brought afterwards. In my opinion you just have to show up and let the medical staff take care of you and guide you.

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2011 04:00PM gutsy wrote: This is such a nice group of people here. Just a few more tidbits.  I am able to sleep in a normal bed but with 3 or so pillows propped up. I am a side sleeper, but that is absolutely a no go. I feel the most stiff and experience some pain when I wake up. It is a good time to do some gentle neck and arm exercises. I also find that when I overdue it by not napping or resting during the day, the pain increases. So it is important to rest even when you feel guite energetic. I walk everyday for a good 45 minutes and can do light housekeeping tasks. My plastic surgeon wants me to be off work for at least 4 weeks, eventhough I am feeling pretty good. She told me, this is not the time to shorten yourself.
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2011 04:23PM gutsy wrote: Cindy, I am sorry to hear about the positive nodes. I can understand that you are scared. Things will be much more workable once you meet with your oncologist. Our minds go to dark places, but the oncologists have so much experience and knowledge and will help select the best treatment for you. Chemo is doable, not fun, but you will make it through ok. Keep us posted, we are all here for each other.
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2011 08:50PM - edited Jan 20, 2011 08:51PM by gutsy cms77  I also have significant bruising on my right side, the side which was reduced and lifted. It is going down to my navel. It does not bother me however. It is the side where I had the mastectomy and reconstruction where I feel lots of pulling, numbness and discomfort. It is so hard to know what is normal and what is not to be expected. I had a lumpectomy, snb and chemotherapy before the mastectomy. Something must have worked there was no invasive cancer left in the breast, just insitu, and wide clear margins. It is hard to know if it was the chemo that worked, but overall happy to know that I don't need radiation. On to the hormone therapy. Wishing all good wishes to those waiting to have their surgery. I had wanted to say something earlier, but I was pretty much paralized in fear waiting for my pathology report. Something I need to work on I know.
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2011 11:32PM - edited Jan 26, 2011 11:39PM by gutsy Yes, I had surgery just about 3 weeks ago and I feel really tired after lunch. I am trying not to nap because my sleep is so poor at night. The expectation that I am back at work on the 8th full days. Somehow I want to stay in my own little world and not go back to business as usual. Does that make sense to anybody? The last 6 months since my diagnosis I have been in survival mode, surgery, chemotherapy, surgery again. I was functioning in high alert while waiting for and going through treatment and working at my job. So yes I am tired physically, but especially emotionally tired. I don't think people around me understand that.  Migallen and Mdg good luck tomorrow. All you have to do is show up, get changed and wear what you wore when you were born. I could not even manage to do that, I forgot to take my underwear of. Thank god it was a good pair.
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: gutsy wrote: Hello, Just came back from meeting the surgeon to discuss pathology report. UH. Two spots which were removed were invasive 1.5 cm each, there also appears to be a larger area of ductal insitu which has close margins. No lymph node involvement. She is recommending mastectomy with reconstruction, perhaps chemo first while waiting. I was blown over, as the nurse kept saying good news, good news. You probably only need radiation. I am feeling kind of numb again. Heck would love to hear your experiences. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy now need mastectomy, need your support gutsy oaklandish1
